page.title: 03History of Cannock Chase
page.content: {900 years ago}the Chase was not used for settlement because the soil was too sandy and poor to grow crops. The oak forests were used for hunting. {In 1290} the Royal Estates and hunting rights passed from the King to the Bishops of Lichfield. {In the 16th Century} the forests were cut down for charcoal burning. The charcoal was used in the local iron industry. Soon the Chase became bare and bleak. Sheep nibbled off any new tree shoots. {During World War I}there were 2 large training camps on Cannock Chase, and in World War II there was an R.A.F. training camp. {In the 1920's} new trees were planted by the Forestry Commission. There are lots of coniferous and deciduous trees on the Chase now and lots of picnic spots.
